title: U.S. Stock Futures Slip Ahead of Jobs Report
text:
By Avantika Chilkoti

-- U.S. stock futures slip

-- Treasury yields slightly lower

-- Hong Kong stocks drop

U.S. stock futures were down on Friday, as investors awaited the September U.S. employment report for clues on the health of the world's largest economy.

Futures for the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average were down 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively.

The jobs report later Friday will provide the latest signal on the health of U.S. growth during a period of global turbulence. Investors have grown skittish about the world economy this week amid a series of weak data from the eurozone and the U.S.

Esty Dwek, a strategist at Natixis Investment Managers, said that recent optimism that the global economy would pick up was fading. "The world has had, if not expectations at least hopes, that we would see a bottom, " Ms. Dwek said.

The yield on U.S. 10-year Treasurys edged down to 1.528% on Friday, from 1.531% on Thursday. Bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.

The WSJ Dollar Index, which measures the currency against a basket of its peers, was down 0.2%.

Market watchers will comb the U.S. jobs data for signs of weakness, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy moving forward. Economists expect nonfarm payrolls were up 140,000 during the month, while the unemployment rate held steady at 3.7%. Average hourly earnings are forecast to have risen 3.3% from September 2018.

In U.S. premarket trading, HP Inc. shares dropped 3.8% after the computer hardware company said Thursday it would slash up to 9,000 jobs as part of its restructuring plan.

Elsewhere, the Stoxx Europe 600 was up 0.1% in afternoon trade, after suffering heavy losses earlier in the week.

Among the biggest gainers was oil-and-gas giant, BP PLC. The stock gained 1.1% after chief executive Bob Dudley said he would retire next year.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei gained 0.3%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng was down 1.1% after the city's chief executive, Carrie Lam, said that from Saturday a ban would be implemented on wearing masks at public gatherings, with penalties of up to a year in jail and a fine.

The ban could escalate tensions between the government and protesters, leading to more violent confrontations, according to Francis Lun, chief executive at Geo Securities. "Investors should avoid Hong Kong-related stocks amid worsening social unrest," he said.

Developers Sun Hung Kai Properties and New World Development were down 2.9% and 1.1%, respectively, and Hong Kong subway operator MTR lost 1.9%.

Stock markets in mainland China were closed on Friday.

Later Friday, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will speak at a Fed Listens event in Washington.

At a Wall Street Journal event in New York on Thursday, Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida said the central bank will do what it takes to keep the longest period of U.S. economic expansion going. He added that the central bank takes each policy meeting "one at a time."

In commodities, global oil benchmark Brent crude gained 0.7% to $58.09 a barrel. Gold edged up 0.1%.

Joanne Chiu contributed to this article.
